key_findings: The paper introduces a dual-layer QoE assessment framework that combines objective network metrics (packet loss, delay, jitter, throughput) with subjective user feedback from live-streaming platforms, enabling network operators to predict user-perceived video quality without requiring client-side instrumentation or video content analysis.

A machine learning model was developed using ITU-T P.1203 reference implementation for MOS computation, allowing accurate prediction of user-perceived video quality using only network-side parameters accessible to operators, eliminating dependency on application-level data.

The research presents a semantic filtering and scoring pipeline using large language models to process user comments from live streams, converting qualitative feedback into quantitative MOS scores in a deterministic and reproducible manner, creating a scalable approach to capture subjective user experience.

A comprehensive labeled dataset of 47,894 live-stream comments was constructed with approximately 34,000 identified as QoE-relevant through multi-layer semantic filtering, with each comment enriched with simulated ISP attribution and temporal alignment for practical operator-level analysis.

The framework establishes a three-layer hierarchical QoE model: Access Layer (network metrics), Service Layer (application behavior), and Experience Layer (user perception), providing operators with progressively detailed insights while maintaining operational relevance and measurability at each level.
limitations: The framework relies on simulated ISP attribution rather than real operator data, which may limit accuracy in real-world deployment scenarios
The semantic filtering approach may miss nuanced user feedback that doesn't explicitly mention performance issues but still indicates quality problems
problem_addressed: Bridging the gap between objective network performance metrics and subjective user experience for network operators to assess Quality of Experience without client-side access
prerequisites: Access to live-streaming platform comment data
